ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Respondent
The headset is comfortable.
The controls are easy to use.
The headset is too heavy.
I like using the virtual reality headset.
It is easy to move around in the game.
It was easy to pick things up in the game.
I had enough practice before I started using the game for real.
I would like to use other versions of the game that took place in different places.
It was helpful to see each scene a second time through.
Seeing each scene a second time helped me understand what other characters were thinking.
I would use a version of this game that I could take home and use.
Other kids I know would like to use this virtual reality system.
Virtual reality should be used more in school.
Virtual reality should be used more to help people understand each other.
It would be good if all kids used a game like this.
I liked taking part in this study.
Is there anything else you want to tell us about your experience with the virtual reality system?
How connected did you feel to your Present Self avatar (in the room with the mirror)?
How connected did you feel to your Addiction Future Self avatar (first one in the park)?

How much did the park experience smell like a park?

Miscellaneous comments on study, interview, methodology relevant to this form data

How engaged or invested were you in the experience; that is, how much did you ''buy in'' to the story?
